text:
> When is the deadline? 
the deadline for the organisations to apply to the programme is on February 19th, so likely a few days before that would be good.  but note that the project idea is rather simple, example from last year <https://openastronomy.org/gsoc/gsoc2020/#/projects?project=ccd_processing_package>

> How about rewriting the Naval Observatory Vector Astronomy Software (NOVAS) in Julia?
I'm not familiar with this software, but in principle I'd say "yes!".  however there are a couple of things to keep in mind:

1. this year google scaled down the workload for the students: 18 hours/week, over 10 weeks (last year it was 30 hours/week).  the smaller workload is good a bad: you can't do larger projects anymore, but sometimes there are smaller yet interesting projects.  you need to find something doable in ~180 hours, keeping also in mind that the level of the students may vary, all of those we had so far were beginners with julia

2. I tried to do a somewhat faithful porting of AstroLib with <https://github.com/JuliaAstro/AstroLib.jl> (and it was also part of our first Google Summer of Code!), but I largely regret it nowadays:  AstroLib is a rather inconsistent collection of routines, I'd prefer something more more coherent, a la astropy.  (But AstroLib.jl was the first Julia code I wrote!)  is NOVAS similar to AstroLib in this?

text: to be clear, you can specify the requirements for the project (like level of Julia and/or astronomy knowledge) and of course students will get in touch with you so you can know them (for example can have a quick interview, if you feel like that) and in the end you can choose whether you want to mentor a student, so the final decision is on you (if you're happy with the skills set, etc...)

text: NOVAS is use to generate the positions of all the objects in the annual Astronomical Almanac. The work can be divided into stages, so not all of it needs to be done at once. For example, we can start with tbe basics of precession and system conversion, and conclude with the inclusion of the JPL ephemeris.
